intercom.intercomsdk

Class Intercom

  • java.lang.Object
    • intercom.intercomsdk.Intercom

  • public class Intercom
extends java.lang.Object

    Intercom is your direct line of communication to every user, right inside your app. Intercom's in-app messages are up to 10 times more effective than email too! Send the right messages, to the right users, at exactly the right time.

    How do I track my users?

    In order to see your users in Intercom's user list, you must first register them via your Android application. If you have a place in your application where you become aware of the user's identity such as a log in activity, call one of the following depending on the information you have available for that user:

    If you have both a unique user identifier and an email for your users:

     Intercom.client().registerIdentifiedUser(new Registration().withEmail("bob@example.com").withUserId("123456"));

    If you only have a unique identifier for your users:

     Intercom.client().registerIdentifiedUser(new Registration().withUserId("123456"));

    Finally, if you only have an email address for your users:

     Intercom.client().registerIdentifiedUser(new Registration().withEmail("bob@example.com"));

    You must call one of the user registration methods in order to start communicating with Intercom.

    Can I track unidentified users?

    Yes, absolutely. If you have an application that doesn't require users to log in, you can call:

     Intercom.client().registerUnidentifiedUser();

    If the user subsequently logs in or you learn additional information about them (e.g. get an email address), calling any of the other user registration methods will update that user's identity in Intercom and contain all user data tracked previously.

    I'm using a previous SDK version and this looks different, what has changed?

    We have re-architected the internals of the Android SDK to ensure it is as reliable as possible while tracking your users. We have focused on removing the asynchronous behaviour of the SDK. For example you no longer need to wait for the completion blocks of the old `beginSession` calls before logging events or updating user data. In doing so the SDK is more nimble and reliable than ever before.

    Previous versions of the SDK will migrate with no action required.

    Please contact us directly via Intercom for any support or questions you may have.

      • initialize

        public static void initialize(Application application,
              java.lang.String apiKey,
              java.lang.String appId)

        Initialize the Intercom singleton.

        Must be called before trying to access the object with Intercom.client()

        Parameters:
        application - A reference to the Application
        apiKey - The Android-SDK API key found on the Intercom API Key settings page.
        appId - The App ID of your Intercom app.
        Since:
        0.9.0

      • client

        Returns:
        the Intercom object
        Since:
        0.9.0

      • registerUnidentifiedUser

        public void registerUnidentifiedUser()

        Registers an unidentified user with Intercom.

        If you call registerUnidentifiedUser, all activity will be tracked anonymously. If you choose to subsequently identify that user, all that anonymous activity will be merged into the identified user. This means that you will no longer see the anonymous user in Intercom, but rather the identified one.

        Since:
        0.9.0

      • registerIdentifiedUser

        public void registerIdentifiedUser(intercom.intercomsdk.identity.Registration userRegistration)

        Registers an identified user with Intercom.

        In order to keep track of a specific user, you must identify it with a unique user identifier, an email address, or both. By supplying information like this Intercom provides richer user profiles for your users. This is a userId, supplied by you (e.g. from an existing web service for your product) to represent your user in Intercom, once set it cannot be changed.

        If you are putting the Intercom SDK into an app that has persisted an authentication token or equivalent so your users don't have to log in repeatedly (like most apps) then we advise putting the user registration call in the `didBecomeActive:` method in your application delegate. This won't have any negative impact if you also add it to your authentication success method elsewhere in your app.

        Parameters:
        userRegistration - the Registration for a user
        Since:
        0.9.0

      • setSecureMode

        public void setSecureMode(java.lang.String secureHash,
                 java.lang.String secureData)

        Set the secure hash and data to be used for Secure Mode.

        Secure Mode helps to make sure that conversations between you and your users are kept private and that one user can't impersonate another. In Secure Mode the Android SDK will sign all requests going to the Intercom servers with tokens. It requires your mobile application to have its own server which authenticates the app's users and which can store a secret. More information on secure mode can be found here.

        This should be called before any user registration takes place.

        Parameters:
        secureHash - a HMAC digest of secureData
        secureData - a piece of user data

      • updateUser

        public void updateUser(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> attributes)

        Updates a user in Intercom.

        You can send any data you like to Intercom. Typically our customers see a lot of value in sending data that relates to customer development, such as price plan, value of purchases, etc. Once these have been sent to Intercom you can then apply filters based on these attributes.

        A detailed list of the fields you can use to update a user is available here

        Attributes such as the user email or name can be updated by calling

         Map<String, Object> userAttributes = new HashMap<>();
 userAttributes.put("email", "admin@exaple.com");
 userAttributes.put("name", "Admin name");
 Intercom.client().updateUser(userAttributes);

        Custom user attributes can be created and modified by passing a custom_attributes map. You do not have to create attributes in Intercom beforehand. If one hasn't been seen before it will be created for you automatically.

         Map<String, Object> userAttributes = new HashMap<>();
 Map<String, Object> customAttributes = new HashMap<>();
 customAttributes.put("paid_subscriber", true);
 customAttributes.put("monthly_spend", 155.5);
 customAttributes.put("team_mates", 3);
 userAttributes.put("custom_attributes", customAttributes);
 Intercom.client().updateUser(userAttributes);

        You can also set company data via this call by submitting an attribute map like

         Map<String, Object> userAttributes = new HashMap<>();
 Map<String, Object> companyAttributes = new HashMap<>();
 companyAttributes.put("name", "My Company");
 companyAttributes.put("id", "abcd1234");
 userAttributes.put("companies", companyAttributes);
 Intercom.client().updateUser(userAttributes);

        `id` is a required field for adding or modifying a company. A detailed description of the company model is available here

        Attributes may be a `string`, `int`, `double`, `unix timestamp` or `bool`.

        Parameters:
        attributes - This is a map containing key/value pairs for multiple attributes.

      • logEvent

        public void logEvent(java.lang.String name)

        Log an event with a given name.

        You can log events in Intercom based on user actions in your app. Events are different to custom user attributes in that events are information on what Users did and when they did it, whereas custom user attributes represent the User's current state as seen in their profile. See details about Events here.

        Parameters:
        name - The name of the event that it is going to be logged.
        Since:
        0.9.0

      • logEvent

        public void logEvent(java.lang.String name,
            java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> metaData)

        Log an event with a given name and some metadata.

        Metadata Objects support a few simple types that Intercom can present on your behalf, see the Intercom API docs

         Map<String, Object> metadata = new HashMap<>();
 Map<String, Object> orderDetails = new HashMap<>();
 orderDetails.put("price", 123);
 orderDetails.put("reference_value", "3434-3434");
 orderDetails.put("url", "https://example.org/orders/3434-3434");
 metadata.put("order", orderDetails);
 metadata.put("order_date", 1392036272);
 Intercom.client().logEvent("ordered_item",
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the event you wish to track.
        metaData - a map of simple types to present to Intercom
        Since:
        0.9.0

      • setPreviewPosition

        public void setPreviewPosition(intercom.intercomsdk.enums.IntercomPreviewPosition previewPosition)

        Configure which part of the screen incoming notifications are displayed on.

        Note: The default value is BOTTOM_LEFT This does not change the position of announcements.

        Parameters:
        previewPosition - The IntercomPreviewPosition takes the options: BOTTOM_LEFT, BOTTOM_RIGHT, TOP_LEFT, TOP_RIGHT
        Since:
        0.9.0

      • setMessagesHidden

        public void setMessagesHidden(boolean visibility)

        Toggle visibility of message previews

        Set as true to hide all incoming Intercom messages and message previews in the parts of your app where you do not wish to interrupt users: camera views, parts of a game etc.

        Parameters:
        visibility - true for hidden, false to show
        Since:
        0.9

      • setupGCM

        public void setupGCM(java.lang.String regId,
            int appLogo)

        Turn on GCM (push notifications) to notify users of new messages and replies.

        Note: This should be called when a user logs in. Calling it multiple times will only update the existing key.

        Parameters:
        regId - the gcm registration id for the current user on this device
        appLogo - a resource id for the image you wish to use for GCM messages
        Since:
        0.9.0

      • openGCMMessage

        public boolean openGCMMessage(Uri data)

        Handle the opening of a GCM notification

        This method should be called in the hosts launch activity Pass in the data of the intent eg. `openGCMMessage(getIntent().getData());` Info will be logged if the Intent is null or does not contain our Intercom identifier

        Parameters:
        data - a Uri that contains the data of an intent to check for an Intercom GCM message
        Since:
        0.9.0

      • reset

        public void reset()

        Clear all data from the Intercom SDK

        Reset is used to reset all local caches and user data the Intercom SDK has created. Use this at a time when you wish to log a user out of your app or change a user. Once called, the SDK will no longer communicate with Intercom until a further registration is made.

        Since:
        0.9.0
